title: Episode 15 â€“ Dr. Ghita Carroll & Greening Schools
subtitle: Sarah Arao Mantle of Hope- Thank You Video to the Y on Earth Community for GoFundMe Campaign Support
full_transcript:
[10.1s - 16.5s]: Hi friends, welcome to another edition of the Y on Earth communities stewardship and

[16.5s - 18.3s]: sustainability podcast series.

[19.2s - 25.3s]: And today we have the great honor and privilege of speaking with Dr. Geeta Levinstine Carol

[25.3s - 26.0s]: Hi Geeta.

[26.3s - 27.0s]: Hi Aaron.

[27.5s - 28.7s]: Great to see you.

[28.7s - 29.9s]: Great to see you too.

[31.0s - 36.3s]: Geeta is the sustainability coordinator for the Boulder Valley School District in Colorado.

[37.1s - 41.8s]: She is a pioneer in advancing district level sustainability planning and initiatives

[41.8s - 47.3s]: and her award winning work has touched tens of thousands of students and future leaders.

[48.3s - 53.9s]: Dr. Carol successes include defining a vision and goals for district wide environmental

[53.9s - 59.5s]: sustainability, receiving board of education approval for a policy that supports sustainability

[59.5s - 65.4s]: initiatives and significantly increasing renewable energy technologies, green building

[65.4s - 70.0s]: design strategies and environmental awareness throughout the district.

[70.7s - 76.3s]: She received a PhD in environmental studies from the University of Colorado Boulder and

[76.3s - 80.0s]: Geeta at such a joy to have this opportunity to speak with you today.

[80.0s - 86.0s]: And one of the things I'm most excited to discuss with you and share with our audience

[86.0s - 91.9s]: is that you've been really in the trenches, you could say in a school district making incredible

[91.9s - 92.8s]: transformation.

[93.9s - 101.0s]: And if I might ask, what has been motivating you doing that work over the past several

[101.0s - 101.2s]: years?

[103.7s - 108.3s]: Oh, well, I mean, all of it.

[108.5s - 115.6s]: It's very motivational and inspiring work to be doing, particularly in the arena of education.

[116.0s - 120.2s]: So I did work at CU and higher ed doing this work for about seven years before this job

[120.2s - 124.8s]: and I've been here for 10 years and it seems, and me, it's the heart of the movement and

[124.8s - 126.7s]: the heart of where all this work takes place.

[126.7s - 135.0s]: So I feel very fortunate to be doing work that I am passionate about in an area where,

[135.3s - 136.8s]: you know, it's such a perfect fit.

[138.1s - 143.6s]: I think, you know, sustainability and just learning to be good stewards of our resources,

[143.6s - 151.2s]: first aware of our resources and how our everyday actions are linked to our planets and then

[151.2s - 156.4s]: being able to pass this on and create a generation of kids who are really thinking about this from

[156.4s - 157.9s]: the start and it's really exciting.

[159.6s - 164.5s]: That's absolutely wonderful and it's so great to be able to share your story with our

[164.5s - 164.9s]: audience.

[165.6s - 172.4s]: And, you know, I'm struck by the position that you're in means you are interacting with

[172.4s - 176.0s]: and really working for so many different stakeholders, right?

[176.1s - 183.5s]: You've got the board of education and others within the actual management structure of the

[183.5s - 184.2s]: school district.

[184.2s - 189.5s]: You've got, of course, a whole bunch of teachers, educators and then you've got hundreds,

[189.7s - 193.1s]: thousands of students and their parents and families.

[193.1s - 198.5s]: I mean, it's an incredible nexus point really for this whole regional community, right?

[199.1s - 200.3s]: Oh, yeah, absolutely.

[201.2s - 204.9s]: And does that sometimes introduce complexities, would you say?

[206.0s - 207.2s]: Oh, yes.

[207.9s - 215.4s]: There's a lot of players and a lot of competing priorities and it had, you know, to really

[215.4s - 219.6s]: fully integrate sustainability into our system.

[219.6s - 221.5s]: It needs to happen at all levels.

[222.7s - 227.2s]: So I was, you know, I was sort of brought in at the administrative level where we started

[227.2s - 233.2s]: by creating our sustainability plan and getting in forward support for that, which was really

[233.2s - 233.8s]: important work.

[234.0s - 238.6s]: But meanwhile, there has been, there has been recycling at our schools for, you know, more

[238.6s - 242.9s]: than two decades and there had been work on the maintenance level to move toward more

[242.9s - 248.2s]: efficient lighting and our purchasing level to start purchasing paper with recycled

[248.2s - 248.9s]: content.

[248.9s - 251.5s]: So it happens, it needs to happen in all places.

[251.5s - 257.2s]: There's not one area where you can check off the box and then you've solved the problem.

[257.7s - 259.1s]: Yeah, you know, like, okay, good, we're done.

[259.3s - 259.6s]: We're done.

[259.9s - 260.1s]: Yes.

[260.7s - 266.2s]: Yeah, there's so much incrementally and even sometimes in terms of really big steps

[266.2s - 268.7s]: that can happen and probably needs to happen.

[268.9s - 269.3s]: Yeah.

[270.1s - 270.6s]: Yeah.

[270.6s - 275.6s]: You say if you were looking back over the last 10 years that you've been doing the work

[275.6s - 281.3s]: you're doing, what would you say are one or two of the accomplishments that you feel

[281.3s - 287.4s]: most proud of or that you feel have been really most innovative or impactful in the physical

[287.4s - 287.7s]: history?

[287.7s - 288.4s]: Yeah.

[289.2s - 295.5s]: Well, when I started this work 10 years ago, really the first thing we did was to kind of

[296.8s - 299.2s]: recognize all the awesome things that were going on.

[300.1s - 304.8s]: Again, kind of at the district level, so while schools had been in, engrossed a lot of

[304.8s - 310.0s]: these activities, there wasn't really a kind of district level commitment to recognizing

[310.0s - 311.4s]: and prioritizing that work.

[311.9s - 315.9s]: And then we created our sustainability management system, which is our plan for incorporating

[315.9s - 320.9s]: sustainability into operations and curriculum.

[321.6s - 325.3s]: And I think that was really the right place to start, given where we were.

[325.8s - 331.3s]: It just gave the opportunity at a high level to again, kind of recognize the work, coordinate

[331.3s - 333.4s]: as an organizational system around the work.

[333.7s - 337.7s]: But we had, as part of creating that plan, we brought in community members, we brought

[337.7s - 343.1s]: in staff, we brought in maintenance, teachers, students, University of Colorado, Boulder,

[343.1s - 349.2s]: and other local partners who are also working toward integrating sustainability and partners

[349.2s - 353.1s]: like EcoSpecial who are working to support the work through partnerships.

[355.4s - 359.9s]: So it gave us that opportunity to just align what we were doing and create meaningful and

[359.9s - 360.6s]: measurable goals.

[360.9s - 367.0s]: So it was the first time we had our maintenance people talking with people from CU about things

[367.0s - 372.5s]: like net zero energy or being climate ready as an organization.

[372.5s - 378.8s]: So it was pretty groundbreaking and a great place to start for that reason.

[379.0s - 384.3s]: So our sustainability plan, we decided the most important areas for us to focus on were

[384.3s - 385.0s]: our buildings.

[385.6s - 391.7s]: So how we were operating and in our construction program, what types of things we were doing

[391.7s - 393.8s]: to incorporate sustainability materials.

[393.8s - 399.5s]: So that looks at what we're purchasing all the way to our waste diversion efforts, transportation.

[399.5s - 403.8s]: So how our community is getting to and from our schools and how we're supporting sustainable

[403.8s - 404.4s]: transportation.

[405.1s - 411.3s]: And then of course education, which is the heart of what we're doing and creating opportunities

[411.3s - 415.8s]: for green teams in the school, integrating sustainability into curriculum.

[416.6s - 420.1s]: And also under education includes how we're communicating about sustainability.

[421.3s - 427.4s]: So once we had this plan, it allowed us to do things like in our monthly newsletter

[427.4s - 428.3s]: now to staff.

[428.8s - 433.3s]: We have a sustainability column and things like that go a long way just in terms of kind

[433.3s - 437.5s]: of how it's integrated into the culture as an important priority for them.

[439.0s - 443.9s]: So that's one thing I would say is, you know, I'm proud of and I think it was the right

[443.9s - 447.6s]: place for us to start really laid the groundwork for the direction we wanted to go.

[448.4s - 449.2s]: It's really amazing.

[449.2s - 458.1s]: But it would have outlined the framework that you've created and are working in.

[458.2s - 465.0s]: I imagine that could be useful to some others in other communities that are in similar positions

[465.0s - 469.0s]: or perhaps even thinking about creating similar positions that would help their school districts.

[470.0s - 474.2s]: You know, I'm struck by the way, how many about how many schools are in the district?

[474.2s - 475.1s]: I don't know that number.

[475.1s - 476.3s]: We have 56 schools.

[476.5s - 476.9s]: 56.

[477.2s - 477.8s]: That's really cool.

[478.8s - 483.9s]: And I'm struck by your mention of the collaborative relationship with the university.

[484.9s - 491.5s]: And I imagine for many other communities out there, they may be able to similarly partner

[491.5s - 499.8s]: with a university that is nearby or reasonably close by for them to leverage off of and take

[499.8s - 504.8s]: advantage of some of the resources and capabilities that might exist at that institution.

[504.8s - 507.1s]: It sounds like that's been part of your strategy.

[507.7s - 508.2s]: Absolutely.

[508.5s - 513.8s]: I mean, partnerships in general are a huge part of why we've had the success that we've had here.

[514.7s - 522.1s]: But it is unique that we're in a university town and I absolutely agree that I think that

[522.1s - 525.8s]: higher ed is maybe a little bit further along than K12 although we're catching up in terms

[525.8s - 528.7s]: of our thinking around sustainability and planning for it.

[529.0s - 533.3s]: So they can be a great partner in that way and that they might have already done some

[533.3s - 535.5s]: of the thinking and work and can help support that.

[535.5s - 541.9s]: And then even to the level of that, every semester I have interns from the university who

[541.9s - 543.7s]: help support this work too.

[544.0s - 548.5s]: So one of the barriers is in the time and money but I'm able to partner with the university

[548.5s - 554.0s]: and they get college credit and help do the work actually here in K12 and give them experience.

[554.3s - 556.4s]: So it's on so many levels.

[556.7s - 559.7s]: It's been remarkable collaborative efforts.

[560.2s - 560.6s]: We university.

[561.2s - 562.0s]: That's beautiful.

[562.2s - 563.1s]: That's so beautiful to hear.

[563.5s - 563.6s]: Yeah.

[564.3s - 571.2s]: So I have to ask because as I think you're aware, many of us in the why on earth community

[571.2s - 579.6s]: ecosystem have a real passion for soil gardening and that aspect of cultivating stewardship,

[579.9s - 583.6s]: regeneration, and health and well-being in our lives.

[584.2s - 585.0s]: So I'm just curious.

[585.2s - 590.8s]: In addition to it sounds like you've done a lot of curriculum related work for inside

[590.8s - 591.8s]: the classroom.

[592.4s - 600.5s]: Are you seeing students in the district getting out and hands in soil out to nature forests,

[600.6s - 601.6s]: whatever it might be?

[602.8s - 603.5s]: Absolutely.

[604.7s - 609.9s]: We are seeing more and more opportunities around that and I think that that's exactly where

[609.9s - 614.7s]: you need to start when you're dealing with K12 students is getting them outdoors and connecting

[614.7s - 620.3s]: with nature and they're inherently excited and supportive of doing that kind of thing.

[620.3s - 622.4s]: So it's a wonderful fit.

[622.7s - 625.7s]: So we have gardens and I think about two thirds of our schools.

[625.7s - 631.6s]: So that's one example of how we're connecting kids outdoors and in a lot of our schools are

[631.6s - 636.2s]: again working with community partners who really integrate that garden into the curriculum

[636.2s - 639.7s]: and to their learning, making sure that all the students are getting out at some point

[639.7s - 642.2s]: hopefully multiple times during the year and working in the garden.

[643.0s - 649.4s]: In most cases we are being able to use some of the food in the garden in our lunch rooms.

[650.1s - 657.2s]: Where our food service program is amazing and has done a lot in support of eating local

[657.2s - 664.2s]: food and fresh foods and not only working with the gardens that take field trips to local

[664.2s - 669.6s]: farmers and learning where the food comes from and grows and having a chance to chat

[669.6s - 670.3s]: with the farmers.

[670.3s - 674.3s]: I think in some cases farmers have come into the lunch room where the kids have gotten

[674.3s - 676.7s]: to meet the farmers who are actually growing the food.

[677.3s - 680.0s]: So really a lot of exciting work happening there.

[680.7s - 684.4s]: Through our bonding construction program we've been able to create some outdoor learning

[684.4s - 687.3s]: spaces in some of our schools and that's a really cool way.

[687.8s - 692.5s]: Some of them are actually classrooms that are outdoors that could be used as and some

[692.5s - 698.4s]: of them are just cool spaces that kids can use and explore during free time.

[698.4s - 700.5s]: But really important.

[701.5s - 708.7s]: And our partners, we have really exciting opportunities for schools.

[708.9s - 712.8s]: Our example, all of our second graders have an opportunity to go to Sembrero Marsh,

[713.9s - 719.8s]: which is nearby and located and they get to learn about wetlands and the water cycle.

[720.3s - 724.7s]: They have an amazing view of actually where the water is coming from from this community

[724.7s - 725.5s]: when they're there.

[727.5s - 729.9s]: And other really cool opportunities.

[730.2s - 734.3s]: So again, not to say that we haven't nailed and as integrated as we would like, but it's

[734.3s - 736.3s]: really important to be able to do that.

[736.3s - 738.3s]: That's so wonderful to hear.

[739.9s - 743.1s]: Are you getting an honor and an audio?

[743.6s - 744.3s]: I don't think so.

[744.9s - 745.0s]: Are you?

[745.2s - 748.1s]: If I'm not showing up on your end, I'm not going to be able to do that.

[748.6s - 748.8s]: Okay.

[750.3s - 757.7s]: So let me ask in the years that you've been doing this, I mean, it sounds like you've had

[757.7s - 760.7s]: so many beautiful successes on so many levels.

[760.9s - 765.4s]: And I've got almost a page full of notes here that I've taken as you've been talking.

[766.3s - 769.0s]: What have been some of the challenges?

[769.4s - 778.5s]: What might you be bumping into now or in the recent past that you hope will be resolved going forward?

[778.8s - 779.3s]: Yeah.

[779.9s - 786.9s]: Well, I think the challenges in general come down to challenge those that a lot of missioners might have is just time and money.

[787.4s - 794.0s]: So, yeah, for example, we're in the middle of a huge bonding construction program right now.

[794.5s - 801.3s]: And we are so fortunate that the community has passed and voted to give money to support construction and improvements in our schools.

[803.3s - 814.2s]: But the money was passed several years ago and already it's a very different market than when the projects were defined.

[814.5s - 821.8s]: So budgets are very tight and we have a lot of competing priorities here at the school district all very important.

[821.8s - 841.2s]: So when it gets down to it, we might not be able to fund the best, most efficient heating ventilation and cooling system for a school because we have to make the choice to use the one that has less upfront cost even though in the long term, that might be a more efficient solution.

[841.2s - 843.1s]: So we have to make hard decisions like that.

[843.5s - 852.4s]: It was unlimited money we could create, I think, amazing facilities that were net zero energy and ample day lighting and access to the outdoors.

[853.4s - 858.6s]: But we are doing a lot, but I think we could go even further if money was an issue.

[860.0s - 862.3s]: Yeah, so that's an ongoing challenge.

[862.9s - 867.9s]: And then I think just timed and support.

[868.3s - 876.8s]: So like I said at the beginning, there's no one box you can check to make this happen and you're done and it really takes champions everywhere at all levels.

[877.1s - 887.6s]: So we've come up with some really exciting programs like our shared energy savings program where schools can voluntarily sign up to basically compete to reduce energy.

[888.1s - 909.9s]: So they commit to auditing their school, taking some follow up action and we provide them tools for doing this, educating their schools and then actually competing to reduce energy that we have a dashboard where they can see live energy data and they can see how they're doing and it gets the kids and the teachers all involved in exciting ways and they come up with things that we would not come up with.

[910.8s - 917.7s]: But we can have a great program, but if there's somebody at the schools, you know, to take this on or really supported it's not going to go anywhere.

[917.9s - 931.4s]: So, you know, having and the schools have an enormous amount, but they need to accomplish in every day, you know, just meeting the standards and testing and, you know, there's a lot of priorities that are very important.

[932.2s - 934.7s]: But it's, you know, there's only so much time in today.

[935.7s - 937.4s]: So, yeah.

[937.4s - 937.4s]: 

[937.9s - 951.4s]: Structains, uh, uh, collaborating as you're saying within the community, uh, where the school district is situated has been a really important strength in all of these efforts.

[951.4s - 967.2s]: And I'm struck that you recently shared with me this organization, GreenApple, GreenApple.org, and the way in which they are helping to connect wonderful projects and leadership in communities all over.

[967.8s - 974.7s]: And I looked at the website, GreenApple.org, I really encourage the audience, please check it out. There's a lot there.

[975.4s - 980.4s]: In terms of the programs, they're highlighting days of service, days of action.

[981.3s - 991.4s]: But what tell me how has GreenApple been an important resource to you and how are you seeing it getting traction and utilization in communities all over the place?

[992.0s - 1001.3s]: Yeah. Well, I think it's an awesome resource. It does a lot of things. It helps recognize the great work that's going on at students and at schools.

[1001.3s - 1008.3s]: And it helps connect communities. And so people can see that it's not just their school, their schools doing this all over the world at this point.

[1008.4s - 1009.9s]: I think it's an international resource.

[1010.7s - 1018.5s]: It does provide, on some limited basis, some grant funds that schools can apply for to get kickstart some of these things.

[1019.1s - 1031.1s]: So, I think, you know, we're in a place now with the GreenSchools network and there's a National GreenSchools conference where there's more resources than I've seen to kind of support and recognize these efforts.

[1031.1s - 1035.6s]: And help get them off the ground, no matter where you are. And you know, it also provides examples.

[1035.9s - 1048.6s]: So, if you don't happen to have composting hauler in your community, that doesn't mean that there aren't things that you could get started to support composting or recognizing the food waste issue in your school.

[1048.7s - 1055.1s]: And so you can see how people are handling these types of things and all different types of things. So it's really, really great and powerful tool.

[1056.1s - 1074.8s]: So wonderful. I noticed on their website, they encourage folks to share projects by shouting out via social media using the hashtag green apple day. So it's hashtag green apple day to get connected in with some of the programming that they have going on.

[1075.8s - 1076.2s]: Yeah.

[1077.1s - 1084.8s]: That's great. Yeah. And they've already affected three and a half million students, 900,000 volunteers, 80 countries.

[1085.1s - 1092.2s]: It looks like they're active in. So what an amazing resource for folks to know about and take advantage of.

[1092.7s - 1093.1s]: Absolutely.

[1094.1s - 1106.0s]: Well, let me ask you something else, Gita. So I know you have a very busy day as the sustainability coordinator for a district with 56 schools.

[1106.6s - 1108.4s]: And you're also a mother.

[1108.9s - 1109.1s]: Yeah.

[1109.1s - 1112.1s]: And you have two school aged kids.

[1113.0s - 1129.2s]: Tell me if we were to take a walk in the day of the life of Gita, what does it look like for you when you're not working and with the family and how is sustainability woven into the fabric of your overall.

[1129.2s - 1142.9s]: Yeah. Well, we love to get outside as a family. And again, I think that's the starting point. And that's where you know if you're going to be passionate about this area, you that's where it's got to start is the connection to the outdoors.

[1143.7s - 1145.6s]: So we take family blocks.

[1146.1s - 1155.4s]: We go on family bike rides. We have a garden at our home that the kids are responsible for watering. And then we help harvest and integrate that into what we're eating.

[1157.0s - 1157.6s]: Yeah.

[1158.5s - 1169.9s]: Yeah. We, I mean, we live in a community where we are able to recycle and compost at home. And if they're also calling that out and each week for when it's trash day and compost day.

[1172.3s - 1172.8s]: Yeah.

[1172.8s - 1180.6s]: But it's I, my kids go to school in the district where I work. So they're always asking me how their school compares.

[1181.1s - 1193.7s]: Are they the greenest and are they doing an okay job? So they like to hear about programs that were working on the impact their schools, like putting in water bottle fillers to make it easier to refill water bottles or being a green star school where they can compost at school.

[1194.5s - 1200.6s]: And then it's always fun when I'm there for a program giving a presentation and.

[1200.8s - 1201.3s]: Right.

[1203.1s - 1216.2s]: Well, that's a very good thing. I think of the really beneficial form of competition that can kick in with even at a very young age to have this sense of, hey, how is our school performing relative to others?

[1216.2s - 1229.6s]: For example, a beautiful way to tune the kids into an aspirational framework that is is for the benefit of the community, the environment in the broader world.

[1230.1s - 1230.8s]: Yeah. Yeah.

[1231.3s - 1238.1s]: We actually just this year. I'm pretty excited. We're launching green report cards. So we have a green report card that the schools haven't seen yet.

[1238.1s - 1246.0s]: But where we've just noted all the areas where whether they have a garden and an active green team and what their energy use level is.

[1246.1s - 1253.5s]: And again, it's like Green Apple Day to just really recognize the great work that's happening at the schools and then give them an opportunity to increase.

[1255.4s - 1266.2s]: That's so wonderful. I don't want to put you on the spot, but I'm curious. Are the criteria that you're using for the green report cards available? Is that something you guys will make available?

[1266.2s - 1267.6s]: Absolutely. Yeah.

[1267.9s - 1272.3s]: What a great additional resource that others could look at and perhaps emulate.

[1272.9s - 1284.3s]: Yeah. Yeah. And I think, I mean, you know, recognizing the work is great. I have our shared shavings program where the winners now do get a portion back of their electricity savings.

[1284.3s - 1293.3s]: But we also have this traveling trophy where we've been doing this for eight years. So if you win, you get your name on it. This was our first winner of our co-campus.

[1293.9s - 1298.3s]: And then our winner last year was Heatherwood Elementary. So you get your name on it. You get to keep it for the year.

[1298.9s - 1302.0s]: And then I get it back and I have it now because we're in between school years.

[1302.8s - 1313.8s]: So little things like this, I think can go a long way. You know, this isn't expensive or hard to do. And it's something that the schools are excited about. And once they win it, they want to work hard the next year to keep it again.

[1313.9s - 1316.6s]: So it's a great way to recognize. Yeah.

[1319.6s - 1332.9s]: Certainly educators and parents know that recognizing achievement and reinforcing that kind of behavior is one of the keys to moving, you know, in the direction we want to be moving, right?

[1333.6s - 1346.6s]: Absolutely. Yeah. And I would say, you know, where you can join the party instead of create your own party. So, you know, it's schools already having an event come to that to be able to share this sustainability efforts instead of trying to create a whole new environment.

[1346.6s - 1354.0s]: And then we're going to do something just because as we talked about time is tight and resources are tight. So that's a good way to integrate into what's already going on.

[1355.8s - 1371.3s]: Well, I love that. That's a beautiful, beautiful message with that. I might just take a quick minute to remind our audiences that this is the why on earth communities stewardship and sustainability podcast series.

[1371.3s - 1378.5s]: And we are talking today with Dr. Geeta Carroll, the sustainability coordinator for the Boulder Valley School District in Colorado.

[1379.4s - 1390.2s]: And I want to be sure to mention that folks can connect with you and your work using Twitter at green BVSD for Boulder Valley School District.

[1390.2s - 1409.2s]: So that's at green BVSD. And for any of you folks who would like to take advantage of some really special groovy deals and discounts on the why on earth ebooks and audiobook products, be sure to use the code podcast when you go to why on earth.org slash market.

[1409.2s - 1414.0s]: And we've got a lot of great resources for you there and hope you'll take advantage of that.

[1414.9s - 1432.4s]: My goodness, this whole notion of joining the party and not trying to recreate parties on our own is one that shows up for me in a bunch of different circles, whether I'm speaking with educators, professionals, consultants, even even parents, right and grandparents.

[1432.4s - 1450.1s]: And it seems to me, in part, because of the amazing communication technologies and other tools that we have at our disposal, Geeta, that we really do have this opportunity to do more and more and more collaborating and layering of collaboration in our communities.

[1450.8s - 1457.3s]: Absolutely. Yeah, there's so much there that I think that we can just build on and engage in. And so it doesn't have to be intimidating.

[1457.3s - 1462.4s]: And so it's happening and we can we can all jump in and be part of it.

[1463.3s - 1464.8s]: Yeah, absolutely. That's so fun.

[1465.3s - 1480.9s]: Well, I want to invite you to share any last thoughts or perhaps even words of advice to other professionals and parents, folks who might be working in school districts as well specifically.

[1481.3s - 1483.8s]: Is there anything that you'd like to share with folks?

[1483.8s - 1491.9s]: Yeah, I mean, I think it's just that there's a growing amount of support and network out there that people can can tap into.

[1492.1s - 1511.2s]: So the department of education has a recognition program for schools and districts doing this work and the Center for Green Schools has scholarships that can help support sustainability professionals in schools and district to do this work.

[1512.9s - 1523.4s]: So more than ever, I think there's opportunities to engage. There's a national green schools conference is taking place in Minneapolis this spring.

[1523.8s - 1530.6s]: And that's an opportunity to bring together thought leaders and on the ground heroes that are kind of working every day to bring sustainability and action to schools.

[1530.6s - 1541.0s]: So it's a great time to get involved and you know, you don't have to be a parent or in the schools to be able to help support a program or the work that's going on.

[1542.5s - 1558.3s]: Awesome. Thank you, Gita. Well, and I also want to mention before we sign off that folks can learn more about the work you're doing at the Boulder Valley School District on the web at BVSD dot org slash green.

[1558.3s - 1563.5s]: Yeah, a lot of wonderful links and resources there as well.

[1563.9s - 1573.8s]: Awesome. Yeah, we have links to our sustainability plans on that website and then resources both local and nationally and a lot of other information about our programs.

[1574.1s - 1575.8s]: So great place to start. Thank you.

[1576.8s - 1599.6s]: Well, my goodness, Gita, it's been so great connecting with you today and thank you for taking time out of your busy schedule to share this with folks. My, my profound hope is that folks and communities all over will benefit from some of your recommendations and the example in the in the work that you've been doing for several years now. So thank you.

[1599.8s - 1601.6s]: Thank you so much for the opportunity.

[1602.8s - 1603.8s]: Appreciate it.

[1603.8s - 1605.0s]: Take care.

[1605.2s - 1605.8s]: You too.

segments.text: Hi friends, welcome to another edition of the Y on Earth communities stewardship and
sustainability podcast series.
And today we have the great honor and privilege of speaking with Dr. Geeta Levinstine Carol
Hi Geeta.
Hi Aaron.
Great to see you.
Great to see you too.
Geeta is the sustainability coordinator for the Boulder Valley School District in Colorado.
She is a pioneer in advancing district level sustainability planning and initiatives
and her award winning work has touched tens of thousands of students and future leaders.
Dr. Carol successes include defining a vision and goals for district wide environmental
sustainability, receiving board of education approval for a policy that supports sustainability
initiatives and significantly increasing renewable energy technologies, green building
design strategies and environmental awareness throughout the district.
She received a PhD in environmental studies from the University of Colorado Boulder and
Geeta at such a joy to have this opportunity to speak with you today.
And one of the things I'm most excited to discuss with you and share with our audience
is that you've been really in the trenches, you could say in a school district making incredible
transformation.
And if I might ask, what has been motivating you doing that work over the past several
years?
Oh, well, I mean, all of it.
It's very motivational and inspiring work to be doing, particularly in the arena of education.
So I did work at CU and higher ed doing this work for about seven years before this job
and I've been here for 10 years and it seems, and me, it's the heart of the movement and
the heart of where all this work takes place.
So I feel very fortunate to be doing work that I am passionate about in an area where,
you know, it's such a perfect fit.
I think, you know, sustainability and just learning to be good stewards of our resources,
first aware of our resources and how our everyday actions are linked to our planets and then
being able to pass this on and create a generation of kids who are really thinking about this from
the start and it's really exciting.
That's absolutely wonderful and it's so great to be able to share your story with our
audience.
And, you know, I'm struck by the position that you're in means you are interacting with
and really working for so many different stakeholders, right?
You've got the board of education and others within the actual management structure of the
school district.
You've got, of course, a whole bunch of teachers, educators and then you've got hundreds,
thousands of students and their parents and families.
I mean, it's an incredible nexus point really for this whole regional community, right?
Oh, yeah, absolutely.
And does that sometimes introduce complexities, would you say?
Oh, yes.
There's a lot of players and a lot of competing priorities and it had, you know, to really
fully integrate sustainability into our system.
It needs to happen at all levels.
So I was, you know, I was sort of brought in at the administrative level where we started
by creating our sustainability plan and getting in forward support for that, which was really
important work.
But meanwhile, there has been, there has been recycling at our schools for, you know, more
than two decades and there had been work on the maintenance level to move toward more
efficient lighting and our purchasing level to start purchasing paper with recycled
content.
So it happens, it needs to happen in all places.
There's not one area where you can check off the box and then you've solved the problem.
Yeah, you know, like, okay, good, we're done.
We're done.
Yes.
Yeah, there's so much incrementally and even sometimes in terms of really big steps
that can happen and probably needs to happen.
Yeah.
Yeah.
You say if you were looking back over the last 10 years that you've been doing the work
you're doing, what would you say are one or two of the accomplishments that you feel
most proud of or that you feel have been really most innovative or impactful in the physical
history?
Yeah.
Well, when I started this work 10 years ago, really the first thing we did was to kind of
recognize all the awesome things that were going on.
Again, kind of at the district level, so while schools had been in, engrossed a lot of
these activities, there wasn't really a kind of district level commitment to recognizing
and prioritizing that work.
And then we created our sustainability management system, which is our plan for incorporating
sustainability into operations and curriculum.
And I think that was really the right place to start, given where we were.
It just gave the opportunity at a high level to again, kind of recognize the work, coordinate
as an organizational system around the work.
But we had, as part of creating that plan, we brought in community members, we brought
in staff, we brought in maintenance, teachers, students, University of Colorado, Boulder,
and other local partners who are also working toward integrating sustainability and partners
like EcoSpecial who are working to support the work through partnerships.
So it gave us that opportunity to just align what we were doing and create meaningful and
measurable goals.
So it was the first time we had our maintenance people talking with people from CU about things
like net zero energy or being climate ready as an organization.
So it was pretty groundbreaking and a great place to start for that reason.
So our sustainability plan, we decided the most important areas for us to focus on were
our buildings.
So how we were operating and in our construction program, what types of things we were doing
to incorporate sustainability materials.
So that looks at what we're purchasing all the way to our waste diversion efforts, transportation.
So how our community is getting to and from our schools and how we're supporting sustainable
transportation.
And then of course education, which is the heart of what we're doing and creating opportunities
for green teams in the school, integrating sustainability into curriculum.
And also under education includes how we're communicating about sustainability.
So once we had this plan, it allowed us to do things like in our monthly newsletter
now to staff.
We have a sustainability column and things like that go a long way just in terms of kind
of how it's integrated into the culture as an important priority for them.
So that's one thing I would say is, you know, I'm proud of and I think it was the right
place for us to start really laid the groundwork for the direction we wanted to go.
It's really amazing.
But it would have outlined the framework that you've created and are working in.
I imagine that could be useful to some others in other communities that are in similar positions
or perhaps even thinking about creating similar positions that would help their school districts.
You know, I'm struck by the way, how many about how many schools are in the district?
I don't know that number.
We have 56 schools.
That's really cool.
And I'm struck by your mention of the collaborative relationship with the university.
And I imagine for many other communities out there, they may be able to similarly partner
with a university that is nearby or reasonably close by for them to leverage off of and take
advantage of some of the resources and capabilities that might exist at that institution.
It sounds like that's been part of your strategy.
Absolutely.
I mean, partnerships in general are a huge part of why we've had the success that we've had here.
But it is unique that we're in a university town and I absolutely agree that I think that
higher ed is maybe a little bit further along than K12 although we're catching up in terms
of our thinking around sustainability and planning for it.
So they can be a great partner in that way and that they might have already done some
of the thinking and work and can help support that.
And then even to the level of that, every semester I have interns from the university who
help support this work too.
So one of the barriers is in the time and money but I'm able to partner with the university
and they get college credit and help do the work actually here in K12 and give them experience.
So it's on so many levels.
It's been remarkable collaborative efforts.
We university.
That's beautiful.
That's so beautiful to hear.
Yeah.
So I have to ask because as I think you're aware, many of us in the why on earth community
ecosystem have a real passion for soil gardening and that aspect of cultivating stewardship,
regeneration, and health and well-being in our lives.
So I'm just curious.
In addition to it sounds like you've done a lot of curriculum related work for inside
the classroom.
Are you seeing students in the district getting out and hands in soil out to nature forests,
whatever it might be?
Absolutely.
We are seeing more and more opportunities around that and I think that that's exactly where
you need to start when you're dealing with K12 students is getting them outdoors and connecting
with nature and they're inherently excited and supportive of doing that kind of thing.
So it's a wonderful fit.
So we have gardens and I think about two thirds of our schools.
So that's one example of how we're connecting kids outdoors and in a lot of our schools are
again working with community partners who really integrate that garden into the curriculum
and to their learning, making sure that all the students are getting out at some point
hopefully multiple times during the year and working in the garden.
In most cases we are being able to use some of the food in the garden in our lunch rooms.
Where our food service program is amazing and has done a lot in support of eating local
food and fresh foods and not only working with the gardens that take field trips to local
farmers and learning where the food comes from and grows and having a chance to chat
with the farmers.
I think in some cases farmers have come into the lunch room where the kids have gotten
to meet the farmers who are actually growing the food.
So really a lot of exciting work happening there.
Through our bonding construction program we've been able to create some outdoor learning
spaces in some of our schools and that's a really cool way.
Some of them are actually classrooms that are outdoors that could be used as and some
of them are just cool spaces that kids can use and explore during free time.
But really important.
And our partners, we have really exciting opportunities for schools.
Our example, all of our second graders have an opportunity to go to Sembrero Marsh,
which is nearby and located and they get to learn about wetlands and the water cycle.
They have an amazing view of actually where the water is coming from from this community
when they're there.
And other really cool opportunities.
So again, not to say that we haven't nailed and as integrated as we would like, but it's
really important to be able to do that.
That's so wonderful to hear.
Are you getting an honor and an audio?
I don't think so.
Are you?
If I'm not showing up on your end, I'm not going to be able to do that.
Okay.
So let me ask in the years that you've been doing this, I mean, it sounds like you've had
so many beautiful successes on so many levels.
And I've got almost a page full of notes here that I've taken as you've been talking.
What have been some of the challenges?
What might you be bumping into now or in the recent past that you hope will be resolved going forward?
Yeah.
Well, I think the challenges in general come down to challenge those that a lot of missioners might have is just time and money.
So, yeah, for example, we're in the middle of a huge bonding construction program right now.
And we are so fortunate that the community has passed and voted to give money to support construction and improvements in our schools.
But the money was passed several years ago and already it's a very different market than when the projects were defined.
So budgets are very tight and we have a lot of competing priorities here at the school district all very important.

So when it gets down to it, we might not be able to fund the best, most efficient heating ventilation and cooling system for a school because we have to make the choice to use the one that has less upfront cost even though in the long term, that might be a more efficient solution.
So we have to make hard decisions like that.
It was unlimited money we could create, I think, amazing facilities that were net zero energy and ample day lighting and access to the outdoors.
But we are doing a lot, but I think we could go even further if money was an issue.
Yeah, so that's an ongoing challenge.
And then I think just timed and support.
So like I said at the beginning, there's no one box you can check to make this happen and you're done and it really takes champions everywhere at all levels.
So we've come up with some really exciting programs like our shared energy savings program where schools can voluntarily sign up to basically compete to reduce energy.

So they commit to auditing their school, taking some follow up action and we provide them tools for doing this, educating their schools and then actually competing to reduce energy that we have a dashboard where they can see live energy data and they can see how they're doing and it gets the kids and the teachers all involved in exciting ways and they come up with things that we would not come up with.
But we can have a great program, but if there's somebody at the schools, you know, to take this on or really supported it's not going to go anywhere.

So, you know, having and the schools have an enormous amount, but they need to accomplish in every day, you know, just meeting the standards and testing and, you know, there's a lot of priorities that are very important.
But it's, you know, there's only so much time in today.
So, yeah.
Structains, uh, uh, collaborating as you're saying within the community, uh, where the school district is situated has been a really important strength in all of these efforts.

And I'm struck that you recently shared with me this organization, GreenApple, GreenApple.org, and the way in which they are helping to connect wonderful projects and leadership in communities all over.
And I looked at the website, GreenApple.org, I really encourage the audience, please check it out. There's a lot there.
In terms of the programs, they're highlighting days of service, days of action.
But what tell me how has GreenApple been an important resource to you and how are you seeing it getting traction and utilization in communities all over the place?
Yeah. Well, I think it's an awesome resource. It does a lot of things. It helps recognize the great work that's going on at students and at schools.
And it helps connect communities. And so people can see that it's not just their school, their schools doing this all over the world at this point.
I think it's an international resource.
It does provide, on some limited basis, some grant funds that schools can apply for to get kickstart some of these things.

So, I think, you know, we're in a place now with the GreenSchools network and there's a National GreenSchools conference where there's more resources than I've seen to kind of support and recognize these efforts.
And help get them off the ground, no matter where you are. And you know, it also provides examples.

So, if you don't happen to have composting hauler in your community, that doesn't mean that there aren't things that you could get started to support composting or recognizing the food waste issue in your school.
And so you can see how people are handling these types of things and all different types of things. So it's really, really great and powerful tool.

So wonderful. I noticed on their website, they encourage folks to share projects by shouting out via social media using the hashtag green apple day. So it's hashtag green apple day to get connected in with some of the programming that they have going on.
Yeah.
That's great. Yeah. And they've already affected three and a half million students, 900,000 volunteers, 80 countries.
It looks like they're active in. So what an amazing resource for folks to know about and take advantage of.
Absolutely.
Well, let me ask you something else, Gita. So I know you have a very busy day as the sustainability coordinator for a district with 56 schools.
And you're also a mother.
Yeah.
And you have two school aged kids.

Tell me if we were to take a walk in the day of the life of Gita, what does it look like for you when you're not working and with the family and how is sustainability woven into the fabric of your overall.

Yeah. Well, we love to get outside as a family. And again, I think that's the starting point. And that's where you know if you're going to be passionate about this area, you that's where it's got to start is the connection to the outdoors.
So we take family blocks.
We go on family bike rides. We have a garden at our home that the kids are responsible for watering. And then we help harvest and integrate that into what we're eating.
Yeah.
Yeah. We, I mean, we live in a community where we are able to recycle and compost at home. And if they're also calling that out and each week for when it's trash day and compost day.
Yeah.
But it's I, my kids go to school in the district where I work. So they're always asking me how their school compares.

Are they the greenest and are they doing an okay job? So they like to hear about programs that were working on the impact their schools, like putting in water bottle fillers to make it easier to refill water bottles or being a green star school where they can compost at school.
And then it's always fun when I'm there for a program giving a presentation and.
Right.

Well, that's a very good thing. I think of the really beneficial form of competition that can kick in with even at a very young age to have this sense of, hey, how is our school performing relative to others?
For example, a beautiful way to tune the kids into an aspirational framework that is is for the benefit of the community, the environment in the broader world.
Yeah. Yeah.
We actually just this year. I'm pretty excited. We're launching green report cards. So we have a green report card that the schools haven't seen yet.
But where we've just noted all the areas where whether they have a garden and an active green team and what their energy use level is.
And again, it's like Green Apple Day to just really recognize the great work that's happening at the schools and then give them an opportunity to increase.
That's so wonderful. I don't want to put you on the spot, but I'm curious. Are the criteria that you're using for the green report cards available? Is that something you guys will make available?
Absolutely. Yeah.
What a great additional resource that others could look at and perhaps emulate.
Yeah. Yeah. And I think, I mean, you know, recognizing the work is great. I have our shared shavings program where the winners now do get a portion back of their electricity savings.
But we also have this traveling trophy where we've been doing this for eight years. So if you win, you get your name on it. This was our first winner of our co-campus.
And then our winner last year was Heatherwood Elementary. So you get your name on it. You get to keep it for the year.
And then I get it back and I have it now because we're in between school years.

So little things like this, I think can go a long way. You know, this isn't expensive or hard to do. And it's something that the schools are excited about. And once they win it, they want to work hard the next year to keep it again.
So it's a great way to recognize. Yeah.
Certainly educators and parents know that recognizing achievement and reinforcing that kind of behavior is one of the keys to moving, you know, in the direction we want to be moving, right?

Absolutely. Yeah. And I would say, you know, where you can join the party instead of create your own party. So, you know, it's schools already having an event come to that to be able to share this sustainability efforts instead of trying to create a whole new environment.
And then we're going to do something just because as we talked about time is tight and resources are tight. So that's a good way to integrate into what's already going on.

Well, I love that. That's a beautiful, beautiful message with that. I might just take a quick minute to remind our audiences that this is the why on earth communities stewardship and sustainability podcast series.
And we are talking today with Dr. Geeta Carroll, the sustainability coordinator for the Boulder Valley School District in Colorado.
And I want to be sure to mention that folks can connect with you and your work using Twitter at green BVSD for Boulder Valley School District.

So that's at green BVSD. And for any of you folks who would like to take advantage of some really special groovy deals and discounts on the why on earth ebooks and audiobook products, be sure to use the code podcast when you go to why on earth.org slash market.
And we've got a lot of great resources for you there and hope you'll take advantage of that.

My goodness, this whole notion of joining the party and not trying to recreate parties on our own is one that shows up for me in a bunch of different circles, whether I'm speaking with educators, professionals, consultants, even even parents, right and grandparents.

And it seems to me, in part, because of the amazing communication technologies and other tools that we have at our disposal, Geeta, that we really do have this opportunity to do more and more and more collaborating and layering of collaboration in our communities.
Absolutely. Yeah, there's so much there that I think that we can just build on and engage in. And so it doesn't have to be intimidating.
And so it's happening and we can we can all jump in and be part of it.
Yeah, absolutely. That's so fun.
Well, I want to invite you to share any last thoughts or perhaps even words of advice to other professionals and parents, folks who might be working in school districts as well specifically.
Is there anything that you'd like to share with folks?
Yeah, I mean, I think it's just that there's a growing amount of support and network out there that people can can tap into.

So the department of education has a recognition program for schools and districts doing this work and the Center for Green Schools has scholarships that can help support sustainability professionals in schools and district to do this work.
So more than ever, I think there's opportunities to engage. There's a national green schools conference is taking place in Minneapolis this spring.
And that's an opportunity to bring together thought leaders and on the ground heroes that are kind of working every day to bring sustainability and action to schools.
So it's a great time to get involved and you know, you don't have to be a parent or in the schools to be able to help support a program or the work that's going on.

Awesome. Thank you, Gita. Well, and I also want to mention before we sign off that folks can learn more about the work you're doing at the Boulder Valley School District on the web at BVSD dot org slash green.
Yeah, a lot of wonderful links and resources there as well.
Awesome. Yeah, we have links to our sustainability plans on that website and then resources both local and nationally and a lot of other information about our programs.
So great place to start. Thank you.

Well, my goodness, Gita, it's been so great connecting with you today and thank you for taking time out of your busy schedule to share this with folks. My, my profound hope is that folks and communities all over will benefit from some of your recommendations and the example in the in the work that you've been doing for several years now. So thank you.
Thank you so much for the opportunity.
Appreciate it.
Take care.
You too.
